newsitem.title: INDIA: India politics weighs on volatile Bombay shares.
newsitem.headline: India politics weighs on volatile Bombay shares.

text.p: Bombay stocks went on a roller-coaster ride on Friday as traders spent the session interpreting political developments that were likely to affect the stability of the ruling 15-party coalition government.

"The uncertain political scenario has pulled down the market," said Anand Bhatt, dealer at YSN Shares & Securities Pvt Ltd. "Unless the political scene gets clear, I don't see the market going anywhere."
The scandal-tainted chief minister of India's eastern state of Bihar said on Friday he was resigning from his post, but immediately named his wife as his successor.

Laloo Prasad Yadav resigned less than an hour after India's Supreme Court ordered that he could not be arrested despite arrest warrants issued against him and three other politicians by a special investigative court.

The crisis has sharply divided the country's ruling United Front coalition, whose leaders put off until Friday evening a meeting on whether or not to allow Yadav's breakaway group to remain in its fold.
Earlier on Friday, news that a special court had issued an arrest warrant against Yadav led to a reaction in share prices.
"I think the market will slide further on fears of political turmoil," said Sanjay Vaid, chief dealer at Lloyds Securities.
"Buying orders of foreign funds could be held back till the full impact is realised."

Yadav's resignation came just as the market closed and dealers said the market outlook would now depend on the political effect of that move. "The key thing now is to be glued to politics," a local dealer quipped.
